technology.short_description: Some hungry Ogre souls were born to serve the Great Maw.
Keep 'em hungry, keep 'em mean.
Scrolls appropriated from Cathay have revealed their deadly secrets…

effects.description: Reload time reduction: +10% for Ironblaster units

technology.short_description: If you hit, throw and generally abuse them enough, Gnoblars occasionally have good ideas – in this instance, a Rhinox-drawn scoop for picking up all the scrap.

effects.description: Upkeep: -25% for Gnoblars, Pigback Riders and Gnoblar Scraplauncher units
Melee defence: +4 for Gnoblars and Pigback Riders units

technology.short_description: These enormous, woolly beasts are notoriously dense, even by Ogre standards, and therefore require a bit of 'encouragement' in the breeding department.

effects.description: Charge bonus: +5 for Sabretusk Pack, Blood Vultures, Yhetees, Thundertusk, Stonehorn, Gorgers and Giant units

technology.short_description: When several smaller Ogre camps become large enough and touch, a bigger gathering – a throng – is formed.
The only forms of currency Ogres will accept are food and gold. When many tribes are working together, agreeing on a standard is vital if healthy relations are to be maintained.

effects.description: Income from sacking and looting settlements: +15%

technology.short_description: The long-abandoned fortresses of the, rarely, if ever-assailed Sky-Titans make ideal campsites for the brighter Ogre tribes.

effects.description: Camp limit: +1 for every level 5 camp built

technology.short_description: The Maneaters have spent their long lives accumulating wealth abroad as mercenaries for foreign powers, giving them a nose for the best plunder and armaments.

effects.description: Melee defence: +2 for Ironguts and Maneaters units

technology.short_description: The Mournfang somehow find themselves ahead of the pack and ready to outflank the enemy. Was it careful planning or did they simply catch the aroma of a tasty meal?
The natural musk of a mighty Mournfang, bizarrely, will attract other animals – ones you want to trap, kill and bung on a spit over the fire with haste.

effects.description: Recruit rank: +1 for Mournfang Cavalry units

technology.short_description: The unwanted cast-offs that have survived in the dark tunnels below the mountains have known nothing but hardship, but are all the stronger for it.
Gorgers like their meat raw or recently slaughtered, so the best kind of bait is the kind that's still wriggling.
Spiked plates attached to the tusks or horns of great beasts make their already deadly swing all the deadlier.
Though it tends to lead to gut-aches and even-more-chronic flatulence than usual, there's sense in depriving the enemy of supplies, so they have to fight you in a weakened state.
Signalling that the several tribes that make up an Ogre kingdom are on the move, as a single, brutish, hungry horde.
It's a bit fiddly, but some Ogres have a natural affinity for such things, and are able to make tents big enough to house a huddle or more.
Whatever it is he's using to flavour the meat makes it taste nicer, and has some healing properties too.
While some Ogres take their camps and travel across the world, others know every inch of their mountainous homelands and rarely leave their birthplace.
It's important to discuss payment from the outset to prevent things going south at a later juncture.
Understanding that the Tyrant's tribute must be paid, no matter how well things went, is essential if you want to carry on living.
Whether it be cannonballs, scrap metal or even picking up the cannon itself and using it like a club, Leadbelchers pack a *serious* punch.
Leadbelchers will fire whatever is at hand at the foe, even grabbing the nearest Gnoblar and sending them flying!
Be it by claw, talon or fang, the beasts of the Ogre Kingdoms tear through even the strongest of defences.
Compared to the cramped, torturous conditions of their beastpens, the battlefield, however savage, is a refreshing break for these creatures.
Ogres have learnt to keep their mostly uncontrollable beasts under control, even when moving between camp locations.
Living in the mountains, Giants often have to bat off falling debris or the attacks of wild beasts, toughening their skin and flesh as a result of the scarring.
As it turns out, many of the Ogres' natural prey are a bit thick and can be tricked into giving up their lives without expending too much effort.
Once you get a handle on the local food supply, things start to come together quite well, quite quickly, regardless of how far the Ogres are from home.

effects.description: Camp growth: +20 when in enemy territory

technology.short_description: Applying Warpstone to steaks before cooking them keeps the number of mutations down.

effects.description:
Chance of a plague spreading: -20%
	(all armies)
Attrition: -50% casualties suffered from Chaos Undivided corruption and Chaos Wastes attrition

technology.short_description: Even Ogres know that keeping records of agreements can avoid the more violent forms of disagreement further down the track; simply sign your name with an 'X'.
Here, all the Ogres of the tribe sit together in one place to eat and make plans (chiefly, to eat even more).
When all is said and done, there's simply no place quite like home.
The megalithic defences of this long-gone race were built into the mountains themselves. It's not completely beyond the Ogres to work out how to use them, but almost.

effects.description:
Defensive supplies: +500 per turn when under siege
	(factionwide)

technology.short_description: Whether made of metal beaten into shape, hide-skins, cart wheels or bone, the thicker an Ogre’s gut plate, the better.
Some mounts are disobedient and others are just plain dangerous, so it's sometimes necessary to "put a bit of stick about" to keep them in line and focused on the task at hand.
Sharper weapons do more damage, something many Ogres learn from watching their Butcher at work.

effects.description: Melee attack: +4 for Ogre Bulls units
Charge bonus: +4 for Ogre Bulls units

technology.short_description: Winding sinew around weapon handles makes for better grip, which in turn makes them easier to wield.

effects.description: Weapon strength: +4% for Ogre Bulls units

technology.short_description: Between battles, Gnoblars are hot on their feet doing whatever their masters demand of them, lest they are turned into dinner.
Gnoblar Trappers delight in tormenting smaller animals and following Ogre Hunters into battle. Baiting them beforehand ensures that only the fastest, most intrepid candidates may attend.

effects.description: [hidden] Used to increase rank for Hunters from camps in conjunction with regular effect (with different scopes)
Leadership: +4 for Gnoblars and Pigback Riders units

technology.short_description: To inflict maximum damage, Ogres might attach scrap metal, stone or even unsuspecting, live Gnoblars to a Giant's club.
When the creatures that live atop the Mountains of Mourn come down into the valleys, they find their stamina levels increased in the thicker air, as if their restraints had been lifted.
A larger campsite means more groupings of tents, and therefore more Ogres gathered in one place – multiplying the threat level many times over.
Gold is useful for opening ears to new ideas.
Those pathetic, snivelling Gnoblars can be leashed and made to sniff out the best loot, and more of it too.
At the heart of every camp lies the Mawtooth stone. The Ogres will fight harder, and with every last breath and ounce of strength, to ensure it is protected.
Simply promising not to eat the foreign envoys puts trade negotiations on a better footing from the outset.

effects.description: Income from trade: +5% for every ally

technology.short_description: This one's not much of a talker, but more of an imposing presence who cracks his knuckles a lot, which speaks volumes to his opposite numbers.
Eating crushed limestone reduces cases of 'Ogre Breath' enough so the Ogres can stand closer together and fight in ranks.

effects.description: Recruit rank: +1 for Ogre Bulls units

technology.short_description: While it's not unheard of, Ogres often don't eat their Gnoblar workers because they are "too stringy", a silver lining that puts most Gnoblars minds at ease.
Recipes and spells are scrawled upon the aprons of the Slaughtermasters and Butchers, steeping them in magic and causing them to absorb even more of the stuff.

effects.description:
Winds of Magic power reserve capacity: +20
	(all armies)

technology.short_description: The bigger the spit, the bigger the meal, the more satisfied the diners.
A couple of Ogres having a conflab quickly becomes a huddle as more and more gather around them.

ui_effects.localised_text: Strong vs units with 25 or more entities

technology.short_description: Now, the Ogres can eat together – bringing a bit of decorum to proceedings, you might say. Almost.

effects.description: Control: -4 in enemy provinces where an army is present

technology.short_description: The volcanic peak kills many when it erupts, so making sure the Fire Mouth gods are appeased should be high on any self-respecting leader's list of things to do.
"The Firebellies are comin' – time for a feast! Who's for some flametoad and devilpepper curry?"

effects.description: [hidden] Used to increase rank for Firebellies from camps in conjunction with regular effect (with different scopes)
